title: Agile Development 101 - Basics of Agile useful for every Netgural
description: Get to know basics of Agile Development, Scrum and how they relate to your daily work in Netguru

cover_slide_data.heading: Agile Software Development 101 - What everyone needs to know
cover_slide_data.intro: Basics of Agile approach & Scrum in 7 Simple Steps.

published_attributes.title: Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Hi! I'm Pola, I've been an Agile Project Manager in NG for over 4y now and I've been researching agile since 2015. This is 7 step intro into agile world. It's focused on Scrum framework and how it relates to usual Netguru experience.

Agenda

  1. Extra short intro for NG attention span ;) - What is Agile and why we need it? üìñ
  2. Agile Product Building in a Nutshell - condensed video + thought provoking questions üé• ‚úÖ
  3. Scrum & Kanban - they don't bite each other üìñ
  4. Scrum Guide üìñ üéß üß™
  5. Scrum: Responsibilities and Roles üìñ ‚úÖ
  6. Scrum: Events üìñ üß™ ‚úÖ
  7. Finito! What's next? ‚úÖ

Legend: üìñ Reading üé• Video üéß To listen üß™ Experiment or Action Point to implement in real life ‚úÖ Exercise or Task in a course

published_attributes.title: What is agile and why we need it?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Agile is a buzzword today. üíé But there is a diamond inside. This course is designed to help you find ways in which agile approach will bring benefits to you.

What is agile software development?

There is a plethora of agile approaches out there - the sensible ones stem from Manifesto for Agile Software Development. This Manifesto was created:

  • by experienced developers
  • over 20 years ago
  • and begins with the words "We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it."‚Üê this quote will be our guide today, to help you and me remember, that we are learning about agile not for the sake of it, but to keep uncover better ways of doing our job.

I strongly encourage You to check out Agile Manifesto and 12 principles behind it.

In my practice Agile Software Development has 2 distinctive features:

  1. It's iterative - done in repetitive cycles
  2. It's empirical - we recognise that predicting the future is extremely hard, and we want to learn by doing

This is definitely enough theory for now - let's see how can it look on an example!

published_attributes.title: Agile Product Building in a Nutshell
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here comes my Agile Mindset Hero - Henrik Kniberg with the best short explanation of Agile Software Development of all times!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

‚úÖ Exercise

Below you will find a set of questions to ponder on during watching - write down your answers and share in the comments!

  1. What Kniberg says about team responsibility for keeping sustainable pace of work? How team can achieve that? Why is sustainable pace important?
  2. If expectation is delivering set scope for set deadline, and prediction shows it's improbable - is it better to reduce scope or extend time?
  3. What is more important according to Kniberg - honesty or delivering agreed scope on time? Why?
  4. What are the risk of different prioritisation of honesty and delivering?
  5. Are there any areas where you disagree with Kniberg? Is some part unclear or unrealistic?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You may now think - well this is very nice on paper, but what about real life, huh?

This is not exactly how Your Netguru projects will look like. This is an industry-wide approach, that we can easily relate to, and discuss how we want to work in a particular case.

A good setup for each project will be slightly different. It's not possible to know it from the beginning. But knowing good practice can help us design better experiments!

With that in mind, let's jump to a crash course about Scrum and Kanban frameworks!

published_attributes.title: Scrum & Kanban
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Scrum

  1. Split your organization into small, cross-functional, self-organizing teams.
  2. Split your work into a list of small, concrete deliverables. Sort the list by priority and estimate the relative effort of each item.
  3. Split time into short fixed-length iterations (usually 1-2 weeks) with potentially shippable code demonstrated after each iteration.
  4. Optimize the release plan and update priorities in collaboration with the customer, based on insights gained by inspecting the release after each iteration
  5. Optimize the process by having a retrospective after each iteration

Kanban

  • Visualize the workflow
    • Split the work into pieces, write each item on a card and put on the wall.
    • Use named columns to illustrate where each item is in the workflow.
  • Limit Work In Progress (WIP) ‚Äì assign explicit limits to how many items may be in progress at each workflow state
  • Measure the lead time (average time to complete one item, sometimes called ‚Äúcycle time‚Äù), optimize the process to make lead time as small and predictable as possible.*

üåü Scrum and Kanban are not contradictory

What I really want you to remember: despite what you may learn from choosing board types on JIRA - Kanban and Scrum are not two exchangeable, separate frameworks.

They are two different set of practices that can be applied together or separately - for example all Scrum teams I've seen were using Kanban board. Did you know that this board is not required by Scrum at all?

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This is once again based on Henrik Kniberg words - if you want to learn more and read some cool case study on implementation of Kanban - check out the source: Minibook: Kanban and Scrum how to make the most of both

* Cycle time and lead time have two slightly separate meanings, but we won't bother with it for now ;)

data.text: Minibook: Kanban and Scrum how to make the most of both

published_attributes.title: Let's dive deeper - Scrum
published_attributes.serialized_body:
As most teams in Netguru work in Scrum-inspired or Scrum-aspiring setup, let's deepen our knowledge of this particular framework.

Best way to do that is by reading Scrum Guide - choose one of the following sources and consume

  • Scrum Guide online or to download in chosen language
  • Illustrated Scrum Guide in pdf

If you prefer listening to reading, or you are a polish speaker and love Krystyna Czub√≥wna I've found good audio versions for you:

  • English Audio Version
  • Polish Audio Version read by Krystyna Czub√≥wna

If you read Scrum Guide before... I strongly encourage you to read it again. Why?

  • Personally, I benefit from re-checking it every few months or years - and this is common for my fellow Scrum users
  • In 2020 there was a substantial update to the Guide - it's shorter and easier to comprehend now!

Honestly, read it before going further.

With the Scrum Guide behind you - let's jump to checking and deepening your knowledge!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ‚úÖ Exercise

Check out the infographic below showing Scrum events and artefacts.

You can hover to see their descriptions on the interactive graphic below:

‚úÖ Now try to assign names to those descriptions. To check your answers - go to the second slide using arrow on the right.

answers.term: 1. List of everything we may want to build
2. Why are we building this product?
3. We create plan for the next (couple of) week(s).
4. List of things to be done this week.
5. What is the goal this week?
6. Inspect and Adapt the plan everyday
7. Inspect and Adapt our plans every week. Ask for feedback.
8. The latest working version of the product
9. Our agreement - what does it mean that something is finished
10. Inspect and Adapt how we work every week.

5. What is the goal this week?
6. Inspect and Adapt the plan everyday

9. Our agreement - what does it mean that something is finished
10. Inspect and Adapt how we work every week.

published_attributes.title: Scrum: Responsibilities - Roles
published_attributes.serialized_body:
All right!

Let's put it into practice - in Netguru you usually work in scrum-inspired setup.

Let's start with Scrum Responsibilities (called Roles up untill 2020):

  1. Developer responsibility: We build high quality product with craftsmanship in mind. Role in Netguru: All designers, developers, QAs and researchers - often from Netguru, sometimes from client side, sometimes from external agency or platform.
  2. Product Owner responsibility: We build what has highest value for stakeholders (users included!). Role in Netguru: Often on client side. In startup setup it's sometimes main stakeholder, sometimes combining this role with other duties. In such setups PO often delegates a lot to Netguru PM. In bigger projects usually a person hired especially for this role. More and more often we work with Product Managers from Netguru side, who are clients hire.
  3. Scrum Master responsibility: We do it effectively, and improve from iteration to iteration. Role in Netguru: Often Netguru PM is filling in at least small part of this role. Sometimes hired separately by client, either from Netguru or directly in client company.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- üß™ Action Point If after reading all that you feel some responsibility is missing, undefined or not fulfilled well in your project - talk to your Project Manager or Project Coordinator. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I really like the switch from "Roles" to "Responsibilities" because with "Role" it was too easy for business/client/sponsor/company to say "we don't need a PO role, we have product-mindset in whole team" and at the same time avoid accountability when the PO responsibilities were not handled well. You don't always have to have a separate role for the PO, SM, DevTeam. But from my (and Scrum Guide authors!) experience - your software development will struggle if any of these responsibilities is not fulfilled.

Let's put it into practice - in Netguru you usually work in scrum-inspired setup.
Let's start with Scrum Responsibilities (called Roles up untill 2020):

Developer responsibility: We build high quality product with craftsmanship in mind. 
Role in Netguru: All designers, developers, QAs and researchers - often from Netguru, sometimes from client side, sometimes from external agency or platform.

Product Owner responsibility: We build what has highest value for stakeholders (users included!).
Role in Netguru: Often on client side. In startup setup it's sometimes main stakeholder, sometimes combining this role with other duties. In such setups PO often delegates a lot to Netguru PM. In bigger projects usually a person hired especially for this role. More and more often we work with Product Managers from Netguru side, who are clients hire.

Scrum Master responsibility: We do it effectively, and improve from iteration to iteration.
Role in Netguru: Often Netguru PM is filling in at least small part of this role. Sometimes hired separately by client, either from Netguru or directly in client company.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
üß™ Action Point
If after reading all that you feel some responsibility is missing, undefined or not fulfilled well in your project - talk to your Project Manager or Project Coordinator. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I really like the switch from "Roles" to "Responsibilities" because with "Role" it was too easy for business/client/sponsor/company to say "we don't need a PO role, we have product-mindset in whole team" and at the same time avoid accountability when the PO responsibilities were not handled well. You don't always have to have a separate role for the PO, SM, DevTeam. But from my (and Scrum Guide authors!) experience - your software development will struggle if any of these responsibilities is not fulfilled.

draft_attributes.serialized_body:
All right!

Let's put it into practice - in Netguru you usually work in scrum-inspired setup.

Let's start with Scrum Responsibilities (called Roles up untill 2020):

  1. Developer responsibility: We build high quality product with craftsmanship in mind. Role in Netguru: All designers, developers, QAs and researchers - often from Netguru, sometimes from client side, sometimes from external agency or platform.
  2. Product Owner responsibility: We build what has highest value for stakeholders (users included!). Role in Netguru: Often on client side. In startup setup it's sometimes main stakeholder, sometimes combining this role with other duties. In such setups PO often delegates a lot to Netguru PM. In bigger projects usually a person hired especially for this role. More and more often we work with Product Managers from Netguru side, who are clients hire.
  3. Scrum Master responsibility: We do it effectively, and improve from iteration to iteration. Role in Netguru: Often Netguru PM is filling in at least small part of this role. Sometimes hired separately by client, either from Netguru or directly in client company.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- üß™ Action Point If after reading all that you feel some responsibility is missing, undefined or not fulfilled well in your project - talk to your Project Manager or Project Coordinator. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I really like the switch from "Roles" to "Responsibilities" because with "Role" it was too easy for business/client/sponsor/company to say "we don't need a PO role, we have product-mindset in whole team" and at the same time avoid accountability when the PO responsibilities were not handled well. You don't always have to have a separate role for the PO, SM, DevTeam. But from my (and Scrum Guide authors!) experience - your software development will struggle if any of these responsibilities is not fulfilled.

Let's start with Scrum Responsibilities (called Roles up untill 2020):

Developer responsibility: We build high quality product with craftsmanship in mind. 
Role in Netguru: All designers, developers, QAs and researchers - often from Netguru, sometimes from client side, sometimes from external agency or platform.

Product Owner responsibility: We build what has highest value for stakeholders (users included!).
Role in Netguru: Often on client side. In startup setup it's sometimes main stakeholder, sometimes combining this role with other duties. In such setups PO often delegates a lot to Netguru PM. In bigger projects usually a person hired especially for this role. More and more often we work with Product Managers from Netguru side, who are clients hire.

Scrum Master responsibility: We do it effectively, and improve from iteration to iteration.
Role in Netguru: Often Netguru PM is filling in at least small part of this role. Sometimes hired separately by client, either from Netguru or directly in client company.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
üß™ Action Point
If after reading all that you feel some responsibility is missing, undefined or not fulfilled well in your project - talk to your Project Manager or Project Coordinator. 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I really like the switch from "Roles" to "Responsibilities" because with "Role" it was too easy for business/client/sponsor/company to say "we don't need a PO role, we have product-mindset in whole team" and at the same time avoid accountability when the PO responsibilities were not handled well. You don't always have to have a separate role for the PO, SM, DevTeam. But from my (and Scrum Guide authors!) experience - your software development will struggle if any of these responsibilities is not fulfilled.

published_attributes.title: Scrum: Events
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Check out this infographic with tips (slide 1) with exercise üß™(slide 2) and solution (slide 3) üëá

How's that relevant to our Netguru experience?

Some of our teams have full setup of Scrum events. In smaller projects we often combine Sprint Review and Sprint Planning in a Weekly Call with the client.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ üß™ Action Point The most useful thing you can do is understand what is the purpose of particular Scrum events and ask yourselves (or ask your team on retro!):

  1. Are we missing something by not having this practice?
  2. Do we have another practice that fulfils this purpose?
  3. If the meeting is not a good solution, how can we achieve the goal in another way?
  4. What is stopping us from implementing it?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Be ruthless - Scrum can be hard, it's not designed to be cuddly and easy, it's designed to bring to the surface the real impediments your team faces. If the impediment is "we have too juniorish team" Scrum will make it visible. If the impediment is "we need to invest more time in architecture" Scrum will make it visible. If the impediment is "our PO doesn't have enough focus on this product, thus tasks are not clear for the team" Scrum will make it visible. It may not be pleasant. But only visible problems will be solved. Don't be afraid of naming problems openly.

published_attributes.title: Finito and Next steps...
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Well done! You finished the crash course into Agile!

Now you should be able to:

  1. Understand Agile Product Development from PO perspective
  2. Get inspired by Scrum Guide
  3. Use both Scrum and Kanban practices at the same time ;)
  4. Name elements of Scrum and experiment with implementing and improving them in your day to day job

‚úÖ üß™ Now I have a quest for you:

Jump on #agile channel on slack and ping me @delfin to let me know you finished the course and answer my last question - what is the biggest challenge you face in your current team setup? (I really want to know! If I know, I can make agile tips more useful in the future.)

What's next?

  1. If you want to get more inspiration, stay on #agile channel on slack ;)
    1. You can also check out Agile Practice Area space on Confluence
  2. You can contact me (or PM or Agile Coach you trust) directly on slack, to get some personalised tips (for you or your team!) on how to deepen your knowledge
  3. You can check out my list of recommended agile learning sources on this board

üëáThat's me getting inspired, I hope you got inspired here as well ;) And if you see a way to improve the course - reach out to me on slack!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- illustrations source in this course: created by stories - www.freepik.com pictures: giphy; private archive
